newsitem.title: CHINA: Hong Kong loses vast sea area in China border revamp.
newsitem.headline: Hong Kong loses vast sea area in China border revamp.

text.p: Hong Kong has lost 250 sq km (94 sq miles) of territorial waters under a redrawing of the territory's administrative border with the rest of China.
Hong Kong became a quasi autonomous, special capitalist region of China on July 1 after 156 years as a British colony.
The new map, which keeps Hong Kong sealed off from the rest of China, was issued by the government on Friday and reproduced in the South China Morning Post newspaper on Saturday.
The frontier line was delimited under an agreement with Britain shortly before the flag change, ending a century of confusion over the territory's sea boundaries.

A colonial-era claim to the whole of two huge bays either side of Hong Kong -- Mirs Bay and Deep Bay -- has been trimmed back to give mainland ships access to the coast of the adjacent Shenzhen region of China's Guangdong Province.
But Hong Kong's share of the sea around two outlying island groups, the Po Toi isles and southern Lantau island, has been slightly enlarged to make policing easier, the new map shows.
"It is certainly more convenient," a senior Marine Police officer said.
"I'm not aware of anyone protesting against the new borders," said Chau Chuen-heung, of the Lantau local authority.
While Hong Kong loses a vast area of sea, it gains 91 hectares (227 acres) of farmable ponds as a result of the straightening of the Shenzhen River along the land border with the mainland.
